name: Predicting Loan Defaults with Machine Learning
body:
# Introduction and Objectives.
Peer-2-peer financial institutions like **Lending Club** are exposed to risk from loan default. Explain a bit more, citing previous literature.

Our project applies machine learning techniques to mitigate this risk by creating a predictive model for loan defaults.
Specifically, we are looking at predicting defaults among two populations:

* Lending Club’s current loans
* New Lending Club customers

# Methods.
##Data exploration
We used data from [Lending Club](https://www.kaggle.com/wendykan/lending-club-loan-data), on loans issued by the platform from 2007-2015. There were **887379 loans** in the dataset, and **74 predictor variables**. 

Insert visualizations of trends in the data - milestones 1-3?

##Data pre-processing
We then proceeded to clean the data in the following ways:

1. Removed loans whose "loan status" was "Current". This left us with approximately **250,000 loans** in the dataset.
2. Recoded "loan status" to a variable called "default", with loans being assigned a value of "0" (if they had/were not in default), and "1" (if they had defaulted). Defaulted loans constituted about **16.6%** of all loans. 
3. Removed all predictor variables which contained >70% missing values.
4. Imputed all remaining missing values with the median value of their respective predictor variable column. This approach was relatively unproblematic, as we had a high number of remaining observations in our dataset (250,000). 

## Model fitting
We then split the data into training and testing datasets (60-40), and fit the following 5 models on the training dataset:

* Logistic regression
* Linear Discriminant Analysis
* Quadratic Discriminant Analysis
* Decision Trees
* Random Forests

## Cross-validation
Thereafter, we performed 5-fold cross-validation on the 3 models which most accurately predicted loan defaults in the testing dataset:

* Logistic regression (**C regularization parameter**)
* Decision Trees (**depth of tree**, **minimum number of samples per leaf**)
* Random Forests (**number of trees**)

# Prediction.
##Model predictive accuracy
Our optimal model after cross validation, judged by predictive accuracy on class 1, was **regularized logistic regression**.

![Image of Predictive Accuracy](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/darlian/cs109a_loan/gh-pages/predictive%20accuracy%20-%20table.png)

We tuned the value of the regularization parameter of the logistic regression model, to maximize predictive accuracy on class 1. A **value of 10^-3** generated the best score.

![Image of CV](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/darlian/cs109a_loan/gh-pages/CV_logreg.png)
